Reading List

    Kitchen Confidential by Anthony Bourdain
    Bourdain gives a viewpoint on the culinary world opposite to that of your run-of-the-mill cooking show. I found the writing down to earth and relaxing to consume. The book aside, I have fond memories of my mom and I watching Anthony's shows when growing up. She holds the opinion that he did society a great service by exposing the world to each other's cultures. I wholeheartedly agree. 2/?/2019
    Digital Minimalism by Cal Newport
    Finished this in one sitting. To say I didn't agree with the premise of this book before picking it up would be an understatement. Regardless, the points are summarized and presented in an elegant and unpretentious way. Normally when someone says they don't partake in X social media site you'd think they're out-of-touch with society, but Cal is on point with his observations and criticisms. 3/21/2019
    Bitcoin Billionaires by Ben Mezrich
    An easy, interesting read that details a fun story from the early days of the cryptocurrency world. For the more technical you may have some nitpicks, but if you can look passed that you'll have a good time. 7/10/2019
    10% Happier by Dan Harris
    My mom encouraged me to meditate and sent me to yoga classes as a teen. Being a nimrod, the advice fell on deaf ears. Maybe at this point in my life I'm more open to the idea, but Dan Harris has presented meditation in an approachable and applicable way. The book is well written and exciting to read as it goes through a stressful time in Dan's life. He meets a few other interesting mindfulness experts that help solidify the point (I've also picked up some new to-reads from his suggestions). Whether you've tried meditation before or not, this book takes an honest approach at trying to convince you and is well worth the read. 7/20/2019

Current

  • Thinking, Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahneman
  • Meditation for Fidgety Skeptics by Dan Harris

To-Read for accountability

  • Real Happiness by Sharon Salzberg
  • Going to Pieces without Falling Apart by Mark Epstein
